accessibilityMap.PRIMARY: Joel de la Fuente. as Inspector Kido
Louis Ozawa Changchien. as Paul Kasoura
Macall Gordon. as Anne Crain Walker
Michael A. Cheng. as Terminal Security
Anthony Ingram. as Kasoura's House Boy

textMap.PRIMARY: 3. John expresses his disappointment with Joe
4. Frank details what happened to him after Juliana left
5. Joe tells John what happened with Juliana and the SD agent
6. Arnold asks Juliana to come watch her mother
7. Betty invites Robert over for dinner
8. Joe is forced to call Juliana to discover more information about the film
9. Juliana arrives to check on her mother
10. Joe gets a warm welcome home from Buddy and Rita
11. Juliana catches a glimpse of a ghost
12. Tagomi mourns his family members and tends to his garden
13. Inspector Kido has questions about Juliana
14. The Japanese begin their search of the factory
15. Juliana delivers a document from the trade minister
16. Mark runs into Frank in the market
17. Rita sends Buddy to bed as Joe waits by the phone
18. Robert arrives at the Kasoura household for dinner
19. Arnold tells Juliana the truth about his job and Trudy
20. Paul asks Robert questions about the nuances of American culture
22. Paul and Betty quickly wrap up dinner with Robert
23. John asks Joe about his conversation with Juliana
24. Frank has a proposition for Robert
25. Juliana tells Frank about her encounter with Arnold
28. Tagomi repays his debt to Juliana's compassion
30. Joe arrives in the Japanese occupied states
32. Juliana walks in a daze after learning the truth

accessibilityMap.PRIMARY: John Smith. acted by Rufus Sewell
Joe Blake. acted by Luke Kleintank
Juliana Crain. acted by Alexa Davalos
Frank Frink. acted by Rupert Evans
Lawrence Klemm. acted by Steve Byers
Arnold Walker. acted by Daniel Roebuck
Nobusuke Tagomi. acted by Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa
Inspector Kido. acted by Joel de la Fuente
Sergeant Yoshida. acted by Lee Shorten
Harlan Wyndam-Matson. acted by Jack Kehler
Ed McCarthy. acted by DJ Qualls

textMap.PRIMARY:
In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the Resistance in the Japanese Pacific States use American pop culture references to communicate. 'Kansas' is a nod to the popular children's novel by Frank L. Baum.

Native American 'Code-Talkers' were used during WW2 to transmit messages to others who spoke the same native languages. They would also use their own codes within these languages to relay information.
Moshi Moshi' is a Japanese greeting meaning 'Hi' or 'Hello' which is used when answering the telephone.
The Japanese greeting "ogenki desuka" translates to "how are you?"

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," the Japanese have allowed the continuation of the English language, although knowledge of the Japanese language would allow for a huge social and professional advantage. You would need some grasp of the language to survive in the Japanese Pacific States, and it would be a part of the curriculum of all schools.
Tagomi's home is a reflection of the respect and importance he pays to Japanese traditionalism.

"Meinichi" is the Japanese word to mean the anniversary of a loved-one's death. Shotsuki meinichi originally referred to the first-year anniversary, but over time has come to refer to future years as well. This day is celebrated by praying, visiting the deceased's grave, or spending time and placing items on the family altar inside the home.

Pond and island gardens are the oldest type of Japanese garden. Other types of Japanese gardens are: dry landscape gardens (karesansui) where sand represents water. Tea gardens (Cha niwa) where a visitor is lead through to a Tea House. Stroll gardens (Kaiyushiki teien) are designed to be looked at as you walk through them and Courtyard gardens (Tsubo-niwa) are small gardens that can often be seen between buildings.
Tagomi's neighbor Mrs. Akiyama is donning a traditional at-home kimono.
The tapestries that can be seen near the windows of Tagomi's office translate to: "Biggest, Strongest" and "Peaceful Coexistence."

The murals that line Tagomi's office are a genre of Japanese art called "Fukeiga" meaning landscapes. The art seen on Tagomi's partition is a woodblock print of three triptychs titled "Eight Views of Kanazawa at Night" from 1857.

The chrysanthemum or 'Kiku' is the national flower of Japan - it represents rejuvenation and longevity. The Imperial Seal features a chrysanthemum, which is the most famous of the 150 seals that feature this flower. The flower in different colors holds a different meaning; with white chrysanthemums being used for funerals and placed on graves.
Kyoto, originally founded in 794 and the former capital, is Japan's oldest city and considered the heart of the country.
The dog making an appearance when Robert Childan arrives at the Kasura home is an Afghan hound.
'Konbanwa' is a greeting used in the evening ('Good evening') rather than the daytime greeting of 'Konnichiwa'.
The Japanese word "utsukushi" translated in English means "beautiful."

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," as other races are far inferior to the Japanese in the Japanese Pacific States, they take on the more menial roles in society. Working as a servant to a Japanese family would be common employment for relatively educated white men.

The shoes featured in Childan's "American Artistic Handcrafts" store come from the 1920s. Shoes of this style would have been worn by 'flappers' - a term used to describe women who embodied the female free spirit of the time. Flappers were typically women that had been released from the restrictions of Victorian dress, been given voting rights, and joined the workforce. The older generation looks disdainfully on flappers considering them disgraceful and untamed.

The production design team of "The Man in the High Castle," approached the Kasoura home by first identifying that the Kasouras are a wealthy and modern Japanese couple living in a world of cultural repression - all they can do is grasp culture of the past. They are fascinated by the small details of American culture and collect things that defined America's history. Their mid-century modern home is a reflection of an affluence that few achieve in the Japanese Pacific States.

The Japanese started making whiskey in 1923, when the founder of the Yamazaki distillery traveled to Scotland and spent three years working in various distilleries to learn the craft. However, the industry didn't start to boom until the 1970s. In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," in the Japanese Pacific States, sake would be more commonly consumed as the spirit of choice. Wealthy Japanese, particularly those like the Kasouras, would be able to afford and enjoy whiskey.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," jazz music would not have had a platform to progress from the 1940s onward. The Dixieland Jazz piece that Paul is referencing would be hard to get a hold of, and not widely distributed.

Born in 1831, Sitting Bull (Tatanka Iyotake) is arguably the most well-known Native American chief. He was the son of a Sioux warrior and was killed by police in 1890.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," Native American artifacts are highly sought after by Japanese collectors.

In Philip K. Dick's book, the word 'Historicity,' is used to describe something that has historical significance. "When a thing has history in it..." One object is the same as another object, unless you know the authenticity of the history behind it.

Japanese funerals are very formal and steeped in rituals, as well as traditions that bring together the Shinto and Buddhist faith. It is important to have a body, or some part, so often when soldiers were sent into battle, they would leave behind a lock of hair, which could be used for their funeral should their body be irretrievable. The bodies are cremated and the bone picked from the ashes using large chopsticks and transferred to an urn, or multiple urns. The ritualized process helps to bring a sense of closure to those left behind, and is very important in Japanese culture.

In the world of "The Man in the High Castle," there is a strict hierarchy and other races are inferior to the Japanese within the Japanese Pacific States. Respect is of utmost importance in Japanese culture and the white people of the Japanese Pacific States would be expected to respectfully bow to the Japanese civilians. This is very different from the Reich where white people are superior.

For this introduction into the Japanese Pacific States killing fields, the producers wanted to convey the idea that the peacefulness and beauty of nature is indifferent to the horror of what's going on around it.
